title: Gerrit Coles tosses 15-K gem, Astros lead Rays 2-0 in ALDS
text:
CLOSE

HOUSTON — One night after Justin Verlander was dominant in a Game 1 win over the Rays, the Houston Astros’ other ace was even better.

Gerrit Cole mystified Rays batters with a club playoff record 15 strikeouts, allowing four hits over 7.2 innings in a 3-1 win in Game 2 of the American League Divisional Series.

The victory gave the Astros a 2-0 stranglehold on the best-of-five series as it shifts to Tampa for Game 3 on Monday.

Cole’s effort was boosted by a solo home run from AL MVP candidate Alex Bregman in the fourth inning and Martin Maldonado’s RBI single in the seventh.

Cole walked Willy Adame on his 118th and final pitch, his lone walk of the night.

Roberto Osuna failed to earn a four-out save, striking out Yandy Diaz, who was the go-ahead run to close the eighth but was done in by walks in the ninth.

Astros reliever Will Harris overcame a bases-loaded jam to earn the save with two outs in the ninth after being called in to put out the fire.

Gerrit Cole struck out 15 batters to earn the victory. (Photo: Thomas Shea, USA TODAY Sports)

MAN OF THE MOMENT

Cole became one of seven pitchers to record 15 strikeouts in a playoff game as only Bob Gibson (17 strikeouts, 1968) and Kevin Brown (16, 1998) had more.

Roger Clemens was the last pitcher to set down 15, accomplishing the feat in Game 4 of the 2000 ALCS against the Mariners.

Cole won his 17th consecutive decision after winning his final 16 during his 20-5 regular season.

Combined with Verlander’s seven innings, where he allowed one hit in Game 1, Astros starters have thrown 15 scoreless innings to open the postseason.

GAME 2: Cole makes postseason history with 15 strikeouts

LINARES: After grooming Astros, coach finds a home with Rays

MERCY: Yankees rout Rays in grand fashion

UNLIKELY CONTRIBUTOR

Catcher Martin Maldonado, not considered one of the Astros top bats in an extremely deep lineup, came through with a clutch RBI single in the seventh inning to give Cole and the Astros breathing room.

The journeyman catcher hit .213 in the regular season with 27 RBI. The bloop single was the second postseason RBI of Maldonado’s 20-game postseason career.

The shot came after Yuli Gurriel reached on a throwing error and Carlos Correa belted a double to left field giving the Astros two runners in scoring position.

Correa also added another run with an RBI in the bottom of the eighth.

STATE OF THE SERIES

The ALDS heads to Tropicana Field for a Monday matinee for Game 3, scheduled for 1:05 p.m. Eastern.

The Rays are set to throw former Astros pitcher Charlie Morton, who was the winning pitcher of the AL Wild Card game in Oakland, with their season on the line. Houston will counter with another ace, Zach Greinke, who was acquired midseason in a trade with the Diamondbacks.

In his final regular season start, Greinke came two outs away from a no-hitter in a 3-0 Astros’ win over Seattle, Sept. 25.
description: Gerrit Cole mystified Rays batters with a club playoff record 15 strikeouts in a 3-1 win in Game 2 of the American League Divisional Series.
